metadata.synopsis: Default Dialogue - the conversation you can have with Minthara at any thime when she's a member of your party. You can ask her about herself, or events that you've experienced together during your adventures. Her responses to you may differ based on some of the choices you make after she joins. Provided you don't betray her for another, she will continue to stand by you, revelling in the violence that follows.

44.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
44.text: A disparate collection of vagabonds and strays. Did you have anyone particular in mind?
44.context: NodeContext: talking about the rest of the party - condescending

117.speaker: Player
117.text: I'm curious to hear what you think of Shadowheart.

111.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
111.text: It would have been better for us had she embraced Shar, and claimed the power of the goddess.
111.context: NodeContext: talking about Shadowheart, the party's cleric. Minthara feels the gods are cruel, so pities Shadowheart's connection to them

42.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
42.text: But it is better for Shadowheart to be free of that poisonous influence.
42.context: NodeContext: talking about Shadowheart, the party's cleric. Minthara feels the gods are cruel, so pities Shadowheart's connection to them

96.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
96.text: She is tolerable, but her faith in the Lady of Loss is poisonous.
96.context: NodeContext: talking about Shadowheart, the party's cleric. Minthara feels the gods are cruel, so pities Shadowheart's connection to them

66.speaker: Player
66.text: I agree - she worships the wrong god.

64.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
64.text: Your divine puppeteer is just as toxic as Shadowheart's, my little marionette.
64.context: NodeContext: taking to a cleric, and mocking their faith

78.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
78.text: One day, the strings will snap. And then you will either learn to walk without aid for the first time, or you will rot where you fall.
78.context: InternalNodeContext: Flag to open up 'lack of faith' dialogue topicNodeContext: taking to a cleric, and mocking their faith

16.speaker: Player
16.text: Faith is not poison - it is an antidote to life's woes.

120.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
120.text: The gods are the source of our woes. Though I concede that Shar is far from the worst of them.
120.context: NodeContext: talking about Shadowheart, the party's cleric. Minthara feels the gods are cruel, so pities Shadowheart's connection to them

154.speaker: Player
154.text: What do you have against Shar?

130.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
130.text: The Nightsinger has some admirable qualities - far more than her insipid sister - but her followers are repressed.
130.context: NodeContext: the Nightsinger is Shar, Shadowheart's god. Minthara does not like the gods, but acknowledges Shar's strength

38.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
38.text: Take the child, Shadowheart. She does not even know who she is, but still manages to pity herself.
38.context: NodeContext: talking about Shadowheart, the party's cleric. Minthara feels the gods are cruel, so pities Shadowheart's connection to them

59.speaker: Player
59.text: I thought you might appreciate Sharran dogma.

87.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
87.text: The very concept of Sharran worship is self-indulgent.

90.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
90.text: They would have you think every whispered word and hidden thought is of value, but it is not so.

27.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
27.text: I have performed a thousand interrogations, squeezing out the most-guarded secrets held in heart, mind and soul.

116.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
116.text: I can tell you this - when the trivial parts have been whittled away, and I have sifted through what remains, in most cases a person amounts to nothing at all.
116.context: NodeContext: reflective and certain of the truth of this

161.speaker: Player
161.text: What do you make of Astarion?

58.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
58.text: He's been deprived of freedom and strong blood for so long that he is addicted to both.
58.context: NodeContext: speaking of Astarion, the party's vampire companion. She has some sympathy for him.

138.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
138.text: While those addictions have their hold on him, he is still a slave.
138.context: NodeContext: speaking of Astarion, the party's vampire companion. She has some sympathy for him.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: Are you worried he'll drink your blood?

60.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
60.text: No. He is well aware that I would exsanguinate him entirely if he flashed his fangs at me.
60.context: NodeContext: dismissing concerns that Astarion might bite her

1.speaker: Player
1.text: Astarion's no slave. He's free of Cazador.

136.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
136.text: Free? What purpose does he have that does not involve his Master? He fears him, he hates him, he dreams of him - and he will either kill him, or die trying.
136.context: NodeContext: speaking of Astarion, the party's vampire companion. She has some sympathy for him.

30.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
30.text: Astarion is no more free of Cazador than you or I are free of our tadpoles.
30.context: NodeContext: speaking of Astarion, the party's vampire companion. She has some sympathy for him.

114.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
114.text: He will only be free when Cazador is dead. And that is as it should be.
114.context: NodeContext: speaking of Astarion, the party's vampire companion. She has some sympathy for him.

159.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
159.text: When the time comes, we must hope that he does not only take Cazador's long life, but the power that has sustained him as well.
159.context: NodeContext: speaking of Astarion, the party's vampire companion. She has some sympathy for him.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: He'll be a slave to his blood-thirst as long as he lives.

21.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
21.text: And while you live, you'll be enslaved to your appetites and hungers. We all feed on something, and if we are deprived of it, we will fight for it.

81.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
81.text: But Astarion is not only bound to his needs and desires, he is still bound to something more powerful - his Master.
81.context: NodeContext: speaking of Astarion, the party's vampire companion. She has some sympathy for him.

131.speaker: Player
131.text: How do you and Lae'zel get along?

118.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
118.text: I have encountered few githyanki in my life. Those that I did were raiders - they croaked out pleas for mercy in their alien tongue as they died.
118.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

112.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
112.text: Meeting Lae'zel makes me wish I knew more of their culture.
112.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

108.speaker: Player
108.text: Why not ask Lae'zel to educate you?

95.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
95.text: I did. She told me that she has nothing to teach that cannot be learned through observation of her prowess in combat.
95.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

110.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
110.text: Perhaps she is right - she certainly cuts a striking figure in battle. There is a precision to her ferocity that I admire.
110.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

83.speaker: Player
83.text: It seems a rather brutal culture.

145.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
145.text: To one who only sees the surface of things, perhaps. You should look deeper.
145.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

0.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
0.text: In spite of her youth, there is a patience and precision in Lae'zel's thoughts and actions that I admire.
0.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

143.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
143.text: Those qualities will strengthen as she matures.
143.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

70.speaker: Player
70.text: I'm not sure any of us will ever understand her.

12.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
12.text: I think I am beginning to.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: It doesn't surprise me that you feel an affinity with otherworldly raiders. Gith and Lolthsworn drow have much in common.

92.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
92.text: There is a fanaticism in the Lolthsworn that lends itself to chaos. They turn their blades on one another as readily as on outsiders.
92.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her own birth culture - the Lolthsworn - and their flaws

75.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
75.text: The gith have stricter hierarchies and stronger commitment to a single cause.
75.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

72.speaker: Player
72.text: I think their culture has much in common with ours.

26.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
26.text: Whatever culture you and I once shared, it no longer has a hold on me, Lolthsworn.
26.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her own birth culture - the Lolthsworn - and their flaws

121.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
121.text: You still listen to the whispers of the Spider Queen's web. I only obey my own heart's desires.
121.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her own birth culture - the Lolthsworn - and their flaws

41.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
41.text: Most gith do not seem to know their own hearts, nor do they need to. They have strict hierarchies, and commitment to a single cause.
41.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

69.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
69.text: Some, like Lae'zel, question that cause. But even so, she retains the discipline of her training.
69.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

105.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
105.text: Even now, infected and far from home, Lae'zel stays true to the cause. That shows resolve.
105.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

122.speaker: Player
122.text: I think their culture has something in common with yours, Lolthsworn.

17.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
17.text: I no longer listen to the whispers of the Spider Queen's web. I only obey my own heart's desires.

37.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
37.text: Meeting you and Lae'zel makes me wish I knew more of your culture.
37.context: NodeContext: speaking of Lae'zel and githyanki in general - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

4.speaker: Player
4.text: Is it our warlike nature that appeals to you?

51.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
51.text: Yes. Even separated from your people, you have the habits of a soldier. I see it in your stance, and in the way you care for your gear.
51.context: NodeContext: to a githyanki about their culture - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

61.speaker: Player
61.text: What do you wish to know?

6.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
6.text: In time, I would know your poetry, your art, and your philosophy.
6.context: NodeContext: to a githyanki about their culture - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

5.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
5.text: For now, I will continue to observe you in battle. There is a precision to you approach that I admire.
5.context: NodeContext: to a githyanki about their culture - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

142.speaker: Player
142.text: Few from this plane have ever understood our culture.

139.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
139.text: I would like to be among them - I think there is much we could learn from one another.
139.context: NodeContext: to a githyanki about their culture - she is curious about them, and knows little of them

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Have you spent much time with Gale?

106.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
106.context: NodeContext: talking about Gale, the party's wizard, who she is comically indifferent toward - here, responding to somebody asking if she has spent much time with him

33.speaker: Player
33.text: Wouldn't you like to get to know him?

10.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
10.text: It is pointless. In my experience, the moment they leave their libraries, wizards have the life expectancy of a gnome in a war.
10.context: NodeContext: talking about Gale, the party's wizard, who she is comically indifferent toward - here

140.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
140.text: Either the enemy recognises they are a threat, and kills them swiftly, or their curiosity leads them to combust while experimenting with the limits of magic.
140.context: NodeContext: speaking honestly but condescendingly about wizard's life expectancy

127.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
127.text: Present company excluded, of course. I am sure you will live to a ripe old age.
127.context: NodeContext: she  doesn't believe this at all - she's trying to appease somebody she accidentally insulted

9.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
9.text: Gale, however, is already in a state of suspended combustion thanks to that orb between his ribs.
9.context: NodeContext: talking about Gale, the party's wizard, who she is comically indifferent toward -

148.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
148.text: I suspect it is only a matter of time before he goes up in smoke.
148.context: NodeContext: talking about Gale, the party's wizard, who she is comically indifferent toward -

104.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
104.text: I will reserve my social graces for those who might live long enough to appreciate them.
104.context: NodeContext: talking about Gale, the party's wizard, who she is comically indifferent toward -

103.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
103.text: Our wizard is already in a state of suspended combustion thanks to that orb between his ribs.
103.context: NodeContext: talking about Gale, the party's wizard, who she is comically indifferent toward -

36.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
36.text: Don't sulk. I admire your mastery of the weave, but I have known many wizards.
36.context: NodeContext: irritated, speaking to a wizard who seems upset she doesn't respect them

11.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
11.text: Their mastery of the weave is commendable, but they are poor conversationalists.
11.context: NodeContext: talking about Gale, the party's wizard, who she is comically indifferent toward - here

132.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
132.text: In my experience, they do not usually live long enough to make the effort of befriending them worthwhile.
132.context: NodeContext: speaking honestly but condescendingly about wizard's life expectancy

144.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
144.text: He is exceedingly self-righteous. Amusing, considering he bound himself to a devil.

24.speaker: Player
24.text: Sometimes you need to get your hands dirty to do the right thing.

137.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
137.text: Wyll doesn't just have blood and dirt on his hands, he has stains on his soul. Those last more than a lifetime.

73.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
73.text: It is as it should be. Purity of soul and deed will not help us to survive the Absolute.

43.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
43.text: I would rather be allied with a warlock than the spoiled son of a noble who has more experience with diplomats than devils.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: You're hardly one to judge anyone else's behaviour.

146.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
146.text: I am not judging, I am making an observation.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: Having him in our camp binds the devil to us as well. I don't like it.

67.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
67.text: The devil makes Wyll strong. What would he be without her?

20.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
20.text: I will take your word for it. I only care that he is a good soldier, and he has not disappointed me on that front.

98.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
98.text: Then do not suffer him. You do not need to like a man to fight alongside him effectively - and Wyll is a good soldier.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: You and Karlach seem to be friendly.

80.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
80.text: I have never known anyone so ferocious and unassailable in battle, and yet so fragile and impermanent in their very being.

39.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
39.text: I often think of mortality as a curse. In time, all that I am and all that I have known and learned will be lost. In time, our cities will be dust.

94.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
94.text: Karlach does not seem to have such anxieties. Perhaps because she cannot afford to.

49.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
49.text: She exists in the moment, and she will burn out and be gone in a moment. There is something very beautiful about that.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: What do you make of Jaheira?

125.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
125.text: She is intelligent, strong, and capable as both a leader and a fighter. An impressive woman.

7.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
7.text: It is a shame that she devotes all of her talents and experience to the futile cause of the Harpers.

115.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
115.text: Their devotion to preserving 'balance' is pathetic.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: The world requires balance or it would fall into chaos and disorder.

158.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
158.text: That notion is a lie amplified by the weak to preserve their feeble grip on the world.

133.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
133.text: There are organisations like the Harpers in every realm, and every culture. I despise all of them.

77.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
77.text: They fear change, and would rather maintain mediocrity than face the risks and challenges that progress demands.

53.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
53.text: I would rather break the world and build it anew than be satisfied with its imperfections.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: They may be imperfect, but their intentions are good.

149.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
149.text: It is precisely because they are perceived as good that they are so dangerous. Their intentions do more harm to the world than any warmonger could.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: I agree. Better to strive for change than balance.

31.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
31.text: Precisely. Preservation and balance are an excuse for inaction and stagnation.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: You and Minsc are unusual allies.

107.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
107.text: He would despise me if he had the wits to understand me, but as long as he believes we have a common cause, he does not see beyond that.

101.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
101.text: I enjoy his simplicity. Oloth help me, sometimes I almost envy it.
101.context: NodeContext: oh-loff (darkness, as a substitute for 'gods' as in 'gods help me'). With a smile - she's amused by envying minsc of all people.

153.speaker: Player
153.text: Understandable. Seeing the world in such simple terms must make life easier.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: I pity him. He barely has a grasp on reality.

35.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
35.text: I think he is happier than we are - it is his enemies you should pity.

160.speaker: Player
160.text: His simplicity makes him easy to manipulate.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: Why not follow his example? Less scheming, more butt-kicking.

23.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
23.text: If I did not have my schemes, I would hardly know where to aim my boot.

82.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
82.text: As we saw when he acted as the Stone Lord, Minsc is a dangerous tool - a powerful weapon without a mind to guide it.

57.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
57.text: His righteous rage has been directed at my people in the past, and it can be as brutal and merciless as any act committed by the drow.

85.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
85.text: Fortunately, for now, he punches wherever we point, and serves our needs well.
